wordDefinition: To reduce in amount, degree, or severity.
exampleSentences: The storm abated after a few hours.
She waited for the pain to abate.

wordDefinition: A departure from what is normal, usual, or expected.
exampleSentences: The test results showed an aberration.
His behavior was an aberration from the norm.

wordDefinition: To regard with disgust and hatred.
exampleSentences: I abhor violence in any form.
She abhors being late to meetings.

wordDefinition: Capable of polishing or cleaning a hard surface by rubbing or grinding.
exampleSentences: The abrasive cleaner worked well on the tough stains.
His abrasive manner alienated his colleagues.

wordDefinition: To shorten (a book, movie, speech, or other text) without losing the sense.
exampleSentences: The editor abridged the novel for the younger audience.
The rights of citizens should not be abridged.

wordDefinition: To set or declare someone free from blame, guilt, or responsibility.
exampleSentences: The priest absolved the sinner of his sins.
She was absolved from all responsibilities.

wordDefinition: To restrain oneself from doing or enjoying something.
exampleSentences: He decided to abstain from alcohol.
They agreed to abstain from voting.

wordDefinition: An award or privilege granted as a special honor or as an acknowledgment of merit.
exampleSentences: She received an accolade for her achievements.
The scientist earned many accolades.

wordDefinition: To approach and address someone boldly or aggressively.
exampleSentences: He was accosted by a stranger on the street.
She was accosted by reporters.

wordDefinition: Typically referring to speech or debate: angry and bitter.
exampleSentences: The debate became increasingly acrimonious.
Their divorce was acrimonious.

wordDefinition: To reduce in amount, degree, or severity.
exampleSentences: The storm abated after a few hours.
She waited for the pain to abate.

wordDefinition: To warn or reprimand someone firmly.
exampleSentences: The teacher admonished the students for being late.
She admonished him for his carelessness.

wordDefinition: Excessive admiration or praise.
exampleSentences: The actor enjoyed the adulation of his fans.
She was embarrassed by the adulation she received.

wordDefinition: A state of hardship or misfortune.
exampleSentences: They faced adversity with courage.
Adversity taught him valuable lessons.

wordDefinition: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
exampleSentences: The aesthetic appeal of the painting was undeniable.
She has an aesthetic sense for interior design.

wordDefinition: Friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
exampleSentences: He was an affable host.
She greeted everyone with an affable smile.

wordDefinition: Having a great deal of money; wealthy.
exampleSentences: They live in an affluent neighborhood.
The affluent society enjoys many luxuries.

wordDefinition: A person who believes that nothing is known or can be known of the existence or nature of God.
exampleSentences: He identified as agnostic, unsure of the existence of God.
Agnostic views can lead to deep philosophical debates.

wordDefinition: Brisk and cheerful readiness.
exampleSentences: She accepted the invitation with alacrity.
He moved with alacrity to complete the task.

wordDefinition: To make (suffering, deficiency, or a problem) less severe.
exampleSentences: The medication helped alleviate the pain.
Efforts were made to alleviate poverty.

wordDefinition: To make something bad or unsatisfactory better.
exampleSentences: The new policies were designed to ameliorate living conditions.
Steps were taken to ameliorate the situation.

wordDefinition: Having a spirit of friendliness; without serious disagreement or rancor.
exampleSentences: Their separation was amicable.
They reached an amicable agreement.

wordDefinition: Belonging to a period other than that being portrayed.
exampleSentences: The film's anachronistic costumes were criticized.
Using a typewriter today seems anachronistic.

wordDefinition: A short and amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.
exampleSentences: He told an anecdote about his childhood.
Her anecdotes always entertained the audience.

wordDefinition: Cause someone to become hostile.
exampleSentences: His comments antagonized many people.
She did not want to antagonize her boss.

wordDefinition: A deep-seated feeling of dislike; aversion.
exampleSentences: She felt a strong antipathy towards her boss.
His antipathy to authority was well known.

wordDefinition: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
exampleSentences: There is widespread apathy among the voters.
His apathy towards the project was evident.

wordDefinition: Anxious or fearful that something bad or unpleasant will happen.
exampleSentences: She felt apprehensive about the upcoming exam.
He was apprehensive of the new changes.

wordDefinition: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
exampleSentences: The journey was long and arduous.
Climbing the mountain was an arduous task.

wordDefinition: Showing great care and perseverance.
exampleSentences: He was assiduous in his research.
Her assiduous efforts paid off.

wordDefinition: Having or showing an ability to accurately assess situations or people and turn this to one's advantage.
exampleSentences: She made an astute business decision.
His astute observations helped solve the case.

wordDefinition: Hostile and aggressive.
exampleSentences: His belligerent attitude caused conflicts.
The belligerent nations were on the brink of war.

wordDefinition: Well meaning and kindly.
exampleSentences: The benevolent donor gave a large sum to charity.
She had a benevolent smile.

wordDefinition: Done openly and unashamedly.
exampleSentences: His blatant disregard for the rules was shocking.
The advertisement was a blatant lie.

wordDefinition: To support or strengthen.
exampleSentences: The new evidence bolstered their case.
He tried to bolster his confidence before the interview.

wordDefinition: A harsh, discordant mixture of sounds.
exampleSentences: The cacophony of the city was overwhelming.
A cacophony of alarm bells rang out.

wordDefinition: Cease to resist an opponent or an unwelcome demand; surrender.
exampleSentences: The army was forced to capitulate.
After hours of negotiation, they finally capitulated.

wordDefinition: Able to burn or corrode organic tissue by chemical action; sarcastic in a scathing and bitter way.
exampleSentences: Her caustic remarks hurt his feelings.
The chemical was highly caustic.

wordDefinition: To rebuke or reprimand severely.
exampleSentences: The teacher chastised the students for their behavior.
He was chastised for arriving late.

wordDefinition: To persuade an unwilling person to do something by using force or threats.
exampleSentences: They were coerced into signing the agreement.
He was coerced into making a confession.

wordDefinition: Clear, logical, and convincing.
exampleSentences: Her argument was cogent and well presented.
He provided cogent evidence for his claims.

wordDefinition: Make (someone) feel intimidated or apprehensive.
exampleSentences: The difficult task did not daunt him.
She was not daunted by the challenge.

wordDefinition: Make (someone) weak and infirm.
exampleSentences: The disease debilitated him over time.
The long journey debilitated the travelers.

wordDefinition: Convert (a text written in code, or a coded signal) into normal language.
exampleSentences: They were able to decipher the ancient script.
She deciphered the hidden message in the letter.

wordDefinition: No longer existing or functioning.
exampleSentences: The factory is now defunct.
Many old traditions have become defunct.

wordDefinition: Causing harm or damage.
exampleSentences: Smoking has deleterious effects on health.
The policy changes had deleterious consequences.

wordDefinition: Cheerful and full of energy.
exampleSentences: She was ebullient after receiving the award.
His ebullient personality made him popular.

wordDefinition: Deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources.
exampleSentences: Her musical tastes are eclectic.
The decor was an eclectic mix of modern and vintage.

wordDefinition: Erase (a mark) from a surface.
exampleSentences: The inscription was effaced over time.
He tried to efface all memories of the incident.

wordDefinition: Make (something) clear; explain.
exampleSentences: The professor elucidated the complex theory.
She asked him to elucidate his point.

wordDefinition: The ability to understand and share the feelings of another.
exampleSentences: She felt great empathy for the homeless.
Empathy is an important trait for a counselor.

wordDefinition: Destroy completely; put an end to.
exampleSentences: They worked to eradicate the disease.
The campaign aims to eradicate poverty.

wordDefinition: Make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
exampleSentences: His comments only exacerbated the situation.
The new policy could exacerbate the current issues.

wordDefinition: Treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor; flippant.
exampleSentences: She made a facetious remark.
His facetious attitude annoyed the group.

wordDefinition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
exampleSentences: He became more garrulous after drinking a few glasses of wine.
Her garrulous nature made her popular at parties.

wordDefinition: Impressive or magnificent in appearance or style, especially pretentiously so.
exampleSentences: The palace was grandiose with its marble floors and gold ceilings.
He had grandiose plans for the company's future.

wordDefinition: Fond of company; sociable.
exampleSentences: She was a gregarious and outgoing person.
Gregarious animals like to live in groups.

wordDefinition: Lacking in freshness or originality.
exampleSentences: The hackneyed plot made the movie predictable.
She avoided using hackneyed phrases in her writing.

wordDefinition: Unfortunate.
exampleSentences: The hapless student failed the exam despite studying hard.
His hapless attempts to fix the car only made it worse.

wordDefinition: A lengthy and aggressive speech.
exampleSentences: He delivered a long harangue about the evils of alcohol.
The politician's harangue was criticized for its harsh tone.

wordDefinition: A person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions.
exampleSentences: The iconoclast challenged the long-held traditions of the society.
As an iconoclast, he was always questioning authority.

wordDefinition: Deserving or causing public disgrace or shame.
exampleSentences: His ignominious defeat was a blow to his reputation.
The team suffered an ignominious loss.

wordDefinition: About to happen.
exampleSentences: The storm was imminent and everyone took shelter.
His arrival was imminent.

wordDefinition: Not feeling or showing emotion.
exampleSentences: He remained impassive during the trial.
Her impassive expression gave nothing away.

wordDefinition: Place or deal with close together for contrasting effect.
exampleSentences: The exhibition juxtaposes modern art with classical sculptures.
Juxtaposing the two ideas highlighted their differences.

wordDefinition: Having or showing eagerness or enthusiasm.
exampleSentences: She was keen to start her new job.
He is a keen observer of human behavior.

wordDefinition: Praise and honor received for an achievement.
exampleSentences: He received kudos for his innovative ideas.
Kudos to everyone who helped make this event a success.

wordDefinition: A passionate expression of grief or sorrow.
exampleSentences: She lamented the loss of her friend.
They lamented over the tragedy.

wordDefinition: Sumptuously rich, elaborate, or luxurious.
exampleSentences: They lived in a lavish mansion.
The lavish party impressed all the guests.

wordDefinition: Permissive, merciful, or tolerant.
exampleSentences: The teacher was lenient with the students.
His lenient approach earned him respect.

wordDefinition: Affected by lethargy; sluggish and apathetic.
exampleSentences: The heat made everyone lethargic.
He felt lethargic after the long flight.

wordDefinition: Generous or forgiving, especially towards a rival or less powerful person.
exampleSentences: She was magnanimous in victory.
His magnanimous gesture won everyone's admiration.

wordDefinition: Having or showing a wish to do evil to others.
exampleSentences: His malevolent stare frightened her.
She acted with malevolent intentions.

wordDefinition: Of only moderate quality; not very good.
exampleSentences: The performance was mediocre at best.
He was disappointed with his mediocre results.

wordDefinition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
exampleSentences: She was meticulous in her work.
His meticulous planning ensured success.

wordDefinition: Wicked or criminal.
exampleSentences: The nefarious activities of the criminal gang were exposed.
His nefarious plans were thwarted.

wordDefinition: A sentimental longing or wistful affection for the past.
exampleSentences: She was filled with nostalgia for her college days.
The old photographs gave him a sense of nostalgia.

wordDefinition: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around one.
exampleSentences: She was oblivious to the noise around her.
He was oblivious of the danger ahead.

wordDefinition: Stubbornly refusing to change one's opinion or chosen course of action, despite attempts to persuade one to do so.
exampleSentences: He was too obstinate to admit he was wrong.
Her obstinate refusal frustrated everyone.

wordDefinition: Having unlimited power; able to do anything.
exampleSentences: The ruler was seen as an omnipotent leader.
In mythology, gods are often depicted as omnipotent.

wordDefinition: Ostentatiously rich and luxurious or lavish.
exampleSentences: They lived an opulent lifestyle.
The opulent decor of the palace was breathtaking.

wordDefinition: Characterized by vulgar or pretentious display; designed to impress or attract notice.
exampleSentences: Her ostentatious jewelry attracted everyone's attention.
The ostentatious display of wealth was criticized.

wordDefinition: Able to be touched or felt.
exampleSentences: The tension in the room was palpable.
His disappointment was palpable.

wordDefinition: An outbreak of a disease prevalent over a whole country or the world.
exampleSentences: The COVID-19 pandemic affected the entire world.
Measures were taken to control the pandemic.

wordDefinition: A statement that contradicts itself but might be true.
exampleSentences: The paradox of the situation puzzled everyone.
Her statement seemed like a paradox.

wordDefinition: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
exampleSentences: He was considered a paragon of virtue.
Her work is a paragon of excellence.

wordDefinition: Attractively unusual or old-fashioned.
exampleSentences: The village had a quaint charm.
Her quaint ideas intrigued everyone.

wordDefinition: Complaining in a petulant or whining manner.
exampleSentences: He became querulous in his old age.
Her querulous nature annoyed everyone.

wordDefinition: Having an obstinately uncooperative attitude towards authority or discipline.
exampleSentences: The recalcitrant student refused to follow the rules.
Her recalcitrant behavior caused problems in the group.

wordDefinition: Grimly mocking or cynical.
exampleSentences: He gave a sardonic smile.
Her sardonic comments made everyone uncomfortable.

wordDefinition: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
exampleSentences: She is known for her tenacious spirit.
His tenacious grip on the rope saved his life.

wordDefinition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
exampleSentences: Smartphones are ubiquitous in modern society.
The ubiquitous nature of fast food is concerning.

wordDefinition: Alternate or waver between different opinions or actions; be indecisive.
exampleSentences: He vacillated between joining the army or going to college.
The politician vacillated on important issues.

wordDefinition: Wanting or devouring great quantities of food.
exampleSentences: He had a voracious appetite.
Her voracious reading habit was impressive.

wordDefinition: To decrease in size, extent, or degree.
exampleSentences: The moon waned and the night grew darker.
His influence in the company waned over the years.

wordDefinition: Dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
exampleSentences: Xenophobia can lead to unfair treatment of immigrants.
The rise in xenophobia has caused concern among human rights groups.

wordDefinition: To have an intense feeling of longing for something, typically something that one has lost or been separated from.
exampleSentences: She yearned for her hometown.
He yearned to see his family again.

wordDefinition: Having or showing zeal.
exampleSentences: She was a zealous supporter of the cause.
His zealous approach to work was appreciated by all.
